content: This classic novel by Harper Lee tells the story of Atticus Finch, a lawyer in the Depression-era South, who defends a black man against an undeserved rape charge while teaching his children about prejudice.

You're referring to "To Kill a Mockingbird" by Harper Lee. It's indeed a seminal work in American literature, addressing themes of racial injustice and moral growth in the 1930s American South. The character of Atticus Finch has become iconic for his principled stance and wisdom. If you have any specific questions about the novel or its themes, feel free to ask!
